title: VC Daily: LP Interest in ESG Funds Grows
text:
Venture funds that have a specific climate-tech focus, meanwhile, are raised faster than other venture funds, according to data from Silicon Valley Bank.

Back during the cleantech boom of the mid- to late-2000s, it took climate-focused funds nine months to get to a final close, according to the bank. That time extended to two years in the middle of the last decade, when LP skepticism about such strategies increased.

In recent years, however, growing LP appetite has meant that a median climate-focused venture fund takes just 12 months to reach a final close, five months faster than industry average.

And now on to the news ...

Top News

What ESG proof? Tim Draper's venture firm has raised a $230 million fund, Draper Associates VI, to back startups that the billionaire investor thinks will have a positive impact on the world, WSJ Pro's Yuliya Chernova reports. But don't ask him to measure the firm's ESG impacts.

"We've been doing ESG forever," said Mr. Draper, founder and managing partner of Draper Associates, referring to environmental, social and governance investing. "We want our LPs to know that has been going on."

Mr. Draper, a vocal free-markets proponent, said growing efforts by limited partners and regulators to measure and constrain venture firms to specific ESG criteria are wrongheaded. Draper Associates doesn't use specific criteria to measure its past investments or evaluate new ones, he said. ESG-related investment decisions are based on Mr. Draper's evaluation of the startups' impact on the world. Mr. Draper previously invested in companies including Skype, SpaceX, Robinhood and Theranos.

"When you start putting regulations down, everything gets ruined, particularly in a venture fund," he said. "It's better to think: ‘Is this a future I want?'"

$1 Trillion

Roughly the size of the new infrastructure bill President Biden signed into law to repair the nation's aging roads and bridges, upgrade the electrical grid and expand access to broadband internet.

Chamath Palihapitiya's Social Capital Leads $20 Million Funding Round for Battery Startup

Billionaire Chamath Palihapitiya's Social Capital Holdings Inc. is leading a $20 million funding round for a startup that hopes to use machine learning to address the difficulty of producing electric-vehicle battery components outside China, WSJ reports. Mr. Palihapitiya's venture-capital firm is backing Mitra Future Technologies Inc., a Silicon Valley company aiming to more efficiently make the components needed for rechargeable batteries, the companies said. The $20 million investment is the first significant fundraising round, or Series A, for the startup, which goes by Mitra Chem.

Wholesale Marketplace Faire Raises $400 Million

Online retailer Faire Wholesale Inc. raised $400 million in its third funding round during the past 13 months, valuing the startup at $12.4 billion and enabling it to expand its workforce and its finance function, CFO Journal reports.

Bain Capital Invests $200 Million in Mixpanel

Bain Capital's technology-focused strategy has invested $200 million in Mixpanel Inc., valuing the provider of product analytics systems at $1.05 billion, WSJ Pro's Luis Garcia reports. San Francisco-based Mixpanel's products are used to evaluate how consumers interact with client apps and websites.

Industry News

Funds

Paradigm raised $2.5 billion for a new venture fund to continue investing in the next generation of crypto companies and protocols. Last month, the firm named Matt Mizbani as investment partner. Paradigm's recent investments include Indian cryptocurrency trading startup CoinSwitch Kuber, game developer Sky Mavis and bitcoin mining company Genesis Digital Assets.

JAL Ventures closed its second fund with $105 million in commitments to continue making post-seed and Series A investments in Israeli startups focused on cybersecurity, enterprise software, AI and fintech. With the new fund, the firm aims to invest in 10 companies, and has already backed Novidea, VOOM, IRP and Infinipoint. JAL Ventures' first fund raised $60 million in 2017.

People

Alchemab Therapeutics, which is focused on the discovery and development of naturally-occurring protective antibodies in neurodegeneration and oncology, appointed Young T. Kwon as chief financial and operating officer. He was most recently chief financial and business officer of Momenta Pharmaceuticals. In April, U.K.-based Alchemab Therapeutics said it closed a £60 million Series A round led by RA Capital Management.

Exits

Immersive Labs, which helps teams improve their cybersecurity skills, acquired peer company Snap Labs for an undisclosed amount. U.K.-based Immersive Labs is backed by Goldman Sachs Asset Management, Summit Partners, Insight Partners, Citi Ventures and Menlo Ventures.

E-commerce services provider Cart.com Inc. acquired 180Commerce, which helps brands sell on Amazon, Walmart and other marketplaces. Terms weren't disclosed. In August, Houston-based Cart.com said it raised a $98 million Series B round led by Oak HC/FT.

SpotOn, which offers payments software to restaurants and retail businesses, purchased Dolce Software, a provider of restaurant labor-management software, for an undisclosed sum. Earlier this year, San Francisco-based SpotOn secured $300 million in Series E funding led by Andreessen Horowitz at a valuation of $3.15 billion.

Berlin-based micro-mobility provider TIER Mobility, which recently raised a $200 million Series D round at a $2 billion valuation, acquired bikeshare company nextbike for an undisclosed amount. SoftBank Vision Fund 2 and Mubadala Capital led TIER's Series D funding.

New Money

Podium, a Lehi, Utah-based communication and payments platform for local businesses, scored $201 million in Series D funding, bringing the company's valuation to over $3 billion. Y Combinator Continuity led the round, which saw support from Durable Capital Partners, Arpex Capital, Accel, Album VC, IVP, Sapphire Ventures, Summit Partners and Sorenson Capital.

ThoughtSpot Inc., a San Jose, Calif.-based business data analytics provider, raised $100 million in Series F funding at a $4.2 billion valuation. New investor March Capital led the round, which included contributions from existing backers Lightspeed Ventures, Snowflake Ventures, Khosla Ventures, Fidelity, Capital One Ventures, General Catalyst, Sapphire Ventures and GIC.

Zoomo, an Australian electric vehicle startup providing last mile delivery services, picked up a $60 million Series B investment, including a debt facility from Viola Credit. Grok Ventures led the equity portion, which included participation from Skip Capital, ArcTern Ventures, AirTree Ventures, Clean Energy Finance Corp., Contrarian Ventures and Maniv Mobility.

Netography Inc., a San Francisco-based network security specialist, secured $45 million in Series A funding. Bessemer Venture Partners and SYN Ventures led the round, which included additional support from Andreessen Horowitz, Mango Capital, Harpoon Ventures and Wing Venture Capital. In addition to the financing round, the company named Ben Holladay as chief revenue officer. He was previously senior director, global security sales at Cisco. Patrick Heim, managing partner at SYN Ventures, joined Netography's board.

Imprint, a New York-based startup offering branded payments and rewards products, grabbed $38 million in Series A financing. Kleiner Perkins led the round, with Stripe also participating.

Zesty, an Israeli provider of automated cloud management for engineers, snagged a $35 million Series A round. Lead investor Next47 was joined by Sapphire Ventures, Samsung Next and S-Capital in the funding.

Homebase, a Vietnam-based real estate technology startup providing an alternative to traditional mortgage financing for homeowners in Southeast Asia, landed $30 million in equity and debt funding. Investors included Y Combinator, Partech Partners, Goodwater Capital, VinaCapital Ventures and others.

Aplazo, a Mexico-based buy-now, pay-later platform, fetched $27 million in Series A funding. Oak HC/FT led the round, which included participation from Kaszek and Picus Capital.

Intelligo, an Israel-based provider of a background risk intelligence platform for investment due diligence, nabbed a $22 million growth investment from Felicitas Global Partners.

Writer, a San Francisco-based artificial intelligence writing assistant for companies, collected $21 million in Series A financing. Insight Partners led the round, with Managing Director Ryan Hinkle joining the board. Gradient Ventures and others also contributed to the funding.

Monograph Inc., a San Francisco-based practice operations platform for the architecture, design, engineering and construction industries, closed a $20 million Series B round. Tiger Global Management led the investment, which saw participation from Index Ventures, Homebrew, Parade Ventures, Designer Fund and Tishman Speyer.

Xtend, a Fort Walton, Fla.-based intuitive drone system enabling operators to undertake complex missions more safely, raised a $20 million Series A round. Chartered Group led the funding, which included contributions from lool ventures, I3 Equity Partners, TPY Capital, TAU Ventures, Surround Ventures, Homeward Ventures, NFX and Top Ventures.

Tech News

Buy 12 books, get an NFT: how Gary Vaynerchuk got orders for a million books

Beijing stock exchange launches with some big first-day gains

Ohio sues Meta alleging Facebook parent misled public about its products' effect on children

Roblox, building out the metaverse, looks to bring educational videogames to schools

California settles with Amazon over Covid-19 notifications

Elon Musk mocks Bernie Sanders on Twitter over taxing the rich

Ping. Ding. Chirp. Notifications are driving us crazy.

Around the Web

China's burned-out tech workers are fighting back against long hours (MIT Technology Review)

Seed rounds at $100mm post money (AVC.com)

Research: customers will reward companies for smaller gender pay gaps (HBR)
